intro: Cousinia gaubae, commonly known as the Afghan cottonthistle, is a flowering plant native to Central Asia, particularly Afghanistan and Pakistan. It is a perennial herb that grows in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in rocky soils and mountainous regions. The plant features a rosette of silvery-gray leaves and produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in summer. It is part of the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. Cousinia gaubae is adapted to withstand drought and has a deep root system to access water from deeper soil layers.
